intro: Gynandriris sisyrinchium, commonly known as the golden cupflower, is a flowering plant native to the eastern United States. It belongs to the sunflower family (Asteraceae) and is characterized by its showy, yellow-orange composite flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, open habitats such as meadows and wetlands. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while its stems are erect and often branched. The golden cupflower plays an important role in supporting pollinators like bees and butterflies.
